author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russians Know Putin Will Be Re-Elected, but Many Worry What Comes Next
description: While there is little doubt about the vote’s outcome, there is concern that an emboldened President Putin may use a win to start a new war mobilization.
content: Maria and her husband, Aleksandr, are certain that President Vladimir V. Putin will secure a fifth term as Russia’s leader in the presidential election this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Ukrainian Drones Target Russia on Final Day of Voting, Russian Officials Say
description: An oil refinery was set on fire in southern Russia and air defense forces shot down two drones flying toward Moscow, officials said, as Ukraine continued a flurry of attacks timed for the election.
content: Ukraine fired a volley of exploding drones at Moscow and other targets on the final day of Russia’s presidential vote on Sunday, the local authorities said, continuing a flurry of attacks over the past week timed for the rubber-stamp election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cornelia Channing
title: Entering the ‘Matrix of Language’ With a Crossword Puzzle Fiend
description: Anna Shechtman’s new memoir-history hybrid, “The Riddles of the Sphinx,” explores the gender politics behind one of the world’s most popular word games.
content: Anna Shechtman was 15 when she started building crossword puzzles, and 19 when her first puzzle was published in The New York Times. She later helped to found The New Yorker’s crossword section where, as one of very few female puzzle creators, she has been part of an ongoing effort to diversify the field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Chicago Begins Evicting Migrants From Shelters, Citing Strain on Resources
description: Officials say more than 2,000 people would be evicted by the end of April, as volunteer groups scramble to assist them.
content: Chicago officials on Sunday began evicting some migrants from shelters, joining other cities that have made similar moves to ease pressure on overstretched resources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: How Does Paris Stay Paris? By Pouring Billions Into Public Housing
description: One quarter of residents in the French capital live in government-owned housing, part of an aggressive plan to keep lower-income Parisians — and their businesses — in the city.
content: The two-bedroom penthouse comes with sweeping views of the Eiffel Tower and just about every other monument across the Paris skyline. The rent, at 600 euros a month, is a steal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: Kushner Deal in Serbia Follows Earlier Interest by Trump
description: More than a decade ago, before running for president, Donald Trump expressed interest in developing the same site in Belgrade that his son-in-law now plans to invest $500 million in rebuilding.
content: The plan by Jared Kushner and his business partners to redevelop a prized location in Serbia’s capital, Belgrade, echoes interest from Donald J. Trump a decade ago in pursuing a deal for the site and a similar proposal pushed during his White House term by a top aide now working with Mr. Kushner, a review of the project shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel S. Johnson
title: The Maine Shooter’s Traumatic Brain Injury Didn’t Have to Happen
description: The Maine Shooter’s Traumatic Brain Injury Didn’t Have to Happen
content: It’s hard to explain how it feels to be behind an artillery piece when it fires. First is the roaring sound that no movie can ever match. Then comes the sight: the gun jerking violently, smoke billowing from its tube as the crew scrambles to load the next round. Finally, there’s the physical feeling of the explosion that threw a hundred-pound shell for miles, knocking the breath out of you and causing your bones to shudder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean and Eric Schmitt
title: Niger Orders American Troops to Leave Its Territory
description: The West African country’s military junta said the presence of U.S. forces was “illegal.” Increasingly, West Africans are questioning the motives of Western countries operating in Africa.
content: Niger said it is revoking its military cooperation deal with the United States, ordering 1,000 American armed forces personnel to leave the country and throwing the United States’ strategy in the region into disarray.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: A Doughnut With No Icing
description: Trent H. Evans sends out a few letters.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Hunt, Aaron Esposito, Jack D'Isidoro, John Woo, Daniel Farrell and Andrea Vancura
title: The Sunday Read: ‘Sure, It Won an Oscar. But Is It Criterion?’
description: How the Criterion Collection became the film world’s arbiter of taste.
content: In October 2022, amid a flurry of media appearances promoting their film “Tàr,” the director Todd Field and the star Cate Blanchett made time to visit a cramped closet in Manhattan. This closet, which has become a sacred space for movie buffs, was once a disused bathroom at the headquarters of the Criterion Collection, a 40-year-old company dedicated to “gathering the greatest films from around the world” and making high-quality editions available to the public on DVD and Blu-ray and, more recently, through its streaming service, the Criterion Channel. Today Criterion uses the closet as its stockroom, housing films by some 600 directors from more than 50 countries — a catalog so synonymous with cinematic achievement that it has come to function as a kind of film Hall of Fame. Through a combination of luck, obsession and good taste, this 55-person company has become the arbiter of what makes a great movie, more so than any Hollywood studio or awards ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allan Kozinn
title: Byron Janis, Pianist of Romantic Passion, Dies at 95
description: He had a brilliant career before arthritis in his hands forced him from the stage, but he overcame the condition and returned to performing.
content: Byron Janis, an American pianist renowned for his commanding performances of the Romantic repertory and for his discovery of manuscript copies of two Chopin waltzes, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Hundreds of People a Day Would Walk By and Admire His Work’
description: A Fire Island tradition, a late-night flat-tire fix in the Bronx and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden and Irish Leader Use St. Patrick’s Day Visit to Address Gaza
description: Prime Minister Leo Varadkar, at the White House, referred to his own country’s struggles when saying that “the Irish people have such empathy for the Palestinian people.”
content: President Biden on Sunday used what is normally a festive St. Patrick’s Day celebration at the White House to acknowledge the growing international concern, including among the Irish, over the humanitarian situation of Palestinians amid Israel’s military action in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Art of Middlebrow Politics in America
description: Two new books explore the liberal struggle against the illiberal currents that have plagued American progress.
content: The most successful progressive movements in American history tend to have a middlebrow quality. They are often started by intellectuals and political radicals, but they win converts — and victories — by appealing to conventional values like religious faith and patriotism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Nicole Shanahan Emerges as a Top Candidate to Be R.F.K. Jr.’s Running Mate
description: The Bay Area lawyer and investor, who was once married to a Google co-founder, was a creative force and primary financial backer behind Mr. Kennedy’s Super Bowl ad.
content: The campaign of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. indicated over the weekend that Nicole Shanahan — a Bay Area lawyer and investor who was once married to the Google co-founder Sergey Brin — was among the top picks to be Mr. Kennedy’s running mate on his independent presidential ticket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Selection Sunday
description: Recent changes in college sports have made March Madness even more unpredictable.
content: Happy Selection Sunday!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Phoebe Philo Breaks Her Silence
description: In an exclusive interview, the designer talks about doing things as she wants them done, the weight of expectations and what happens next.
content: The last time Phoebe Philo, who has been called “the Chanel of her generation,” gave a formal interview was a decade ago. The designer, whose work offered women respite from the limits of the male gaze, has never been all that interested in explaining herself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: When Arguing Was an Art, Not a Free-for-All
description: In “The Ancient Art of Thinking for Yourself,” Robin Reames contends that Greek and Roman rhetorical techniques can help us speak — and listen — to one another today.
content: Robin Reames, an English professor at the University of Illinois at Chicago, was frustrated by the intractability of the political arguments she had with her Bible Belt, Fox News-fan father as she took on liberal views in college. She is now similarly frustrated, like so many, by the vast, glum cleft between leftist and rightist ideals, and “The Ancient Art of Thinking for Yourself” joins a recent spate of books seeking to help us to communicate, in the current phrase, “across the divide.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Trump Doubles Down on Migrants ‘Poisoning’ the Country
description: In an interview on Fox News, the former president said again that migrants crossing the southern border were criminals from prisons and mental institutions.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump, in an interview broadcast Sunday, doubled down on his description of immigrants as “poisoning the blood” of the country, language that echoes Hitler.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Monday Briefing: Putin Extends His Rule
description: Also, new avenues to get aid into Gaza are not yet relieving hunger.
content: President Vladimir Putin claimed another six-year term in a presidential contest in which he faced no real competition. He is expected to hold a Red Square rally to formally declare victory — and to portray the vote as a public endorsement of his invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Now Arriving at J.F.K.: Horses From Iceland and Dogs From the West Bank
description: The ARK, a 14-acre facility at Kennedy International Airport, is often the first stop for animals of all kinds arriving in the United States.
content: When the cargo plane touched down on the tarmac at Kennedy International Airport on Friday afternoon, a cacophonous barking could be heard coming from the hold.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 17, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 17, 2024.
content: A headline with an article on Saturday about a violent altercation on a subway line in Brooklyn referred incorrectly to the condition of the man who was shot in the head. He is in critical but stable condition. He was not killed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 18, 2024
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts
title: Haitian Migrant in Massachusetts Is Charged With Raping a Teenager
description: The suspect and the 15-year-old were both living in a hotel that currently serves as a migrants shelter. The charge comes amid heightened scrutiny over America’s immigration policy.
content: A Haitian migrant has been charged with raping a 15-year-old girl at a hotel serving as a migrant shelter in Massachusetts, authorities said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon, Vivian Yee, Gaya Gupta and David Segal
title: ‘We’re Not a Banana Republic,’ Netanyahu Says, Rejecting Criticism From U.S.
description: The Israeli leader lashed back at a call from a prominent Democratic senator for elections in Israel.
content: The rift over the war in Gaza between Israel and the United States, its closest ally, broadened on Sunday when Israel’s prime minister accused a top-ranking American lawmaker of treating his country like a “banana republic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Schiffman
title: Few Smartphones, Some Beer: A Christian Village Grapples With Modernity
description: A rare look at how the Bruderhof of the Hudson Valley navigate the outside world while keeping it at arm’s length.
content: It was early afternoon on a sunny winter Thursday, and the Fox Hill community looked like a well-manicured ghost town abandoned in the 1950s. Stately multistoried homes were scattered across a parklike landscape of gently rolling hills and ponds, a bucolic settlement of 60 acres in the Hudson Valley of New York State. But where was everyone?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Minho Kim
title: Khanna Explains Opposition to TikTok Bill While Senators Signal Openness
description: The California Democrat Ro Khanna pointed to the need for a federal data privacy law, and a Democrat and a Republican in the Senate suggested sympathy for the calls to ban the app.
content: Representative Ro Khanna, the California Democrat representing Silicon Valley, laid out his case against a sweeping ban of the social media platform TikTok on Sunday after opposing legislation that overwhelmingly passed the House last week, saying the bill would be ineffective.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilan Stavans
title: Will Mexico’s Claudia Sheinbaum, a Jewish Woman, Blaze a Trail or Follow One?
description: Her ascent shows how pluralism has redefined the country’s texture.
content: Mexico’s presidential campaign is well underway and if the polls are to be believed, Claudia Sheinbaum, a physicist and candidate of the left-leaning ruling Morena party, could be the country’s next president. Ms. Sheinbaum, who is of Jewish descent, holds a staggering 30 percentage point lead over Xóchitl Gálvez, a tech entrepreneur of Indigenous descent. However, the election is not until June 2, and politics, like life, is full of surprises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Margaret Grade, Whose California Inn Was Beloved by Stars, Dies at 72
description: Her Manka’s Inverness Lodge drew actors and writers who dined at Ms. Grade’s farm-to-table restaurant and reveled in her eccentric flair.
content: Margaret Grade, a California neuropsychologist who made a sharp career turn to open a cozy, eclectic inn near the Point Reyes National Seashore that was known for tending to farmers and fishers with the same attentiveness it gave to the film stars and writers who sought sanctuary there, died on Feb. 28 in San Francisco. She was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Chef Helping Send Aid Ships to Gaza Calls for a Cease-Fire
description: The chef, José Andrés, also said that he hoped his group, World Central Kitchen, would be eventually able to transport “huge quantities of food daily into the shores of Gaza.”
content: As a second ship towing desperately needed aid prepared to depart for Gaza on Sunday, José Andrés, the founder of the food charity sending the vessels, called for a cease-fire and said that Israel should be doing more to prevent hunger in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: What Trump’s TikTok Flip-Flop Tells America
description: On yet another issue, Trump sides with a foreign adversary over America.
content: When the House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly last Wednesday to pass a bill that would require TikTok to divest its Chinese ownership or face an American ban, it provided a glimmer of hope in a dreary political time. This is exactly what a nation should do when it’s getting serious about the national security threat posed by the People’s Republic of China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Freeman
title: The Best Way to Find Out if We Can Cool the Planet
description: High-stakes geoengineering science requires transparency and accountability to the public.
content: A few years ago, the idea of deliberately blocking the sun to combat climate change was taboo for scientists. But a lot can change in a short time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and Cade Metz
title: In Latest A.I. War Escalation, Elon Musk Releases Chatbot Code
description: Mr. Musk’s move to open up the code behind Grok is the latest volley in a war to win the A.I. battle, after a suit against OpenAI on the same topic.
content: Elon Musk released the raw computer code behind his version of an artificial intelligence chatbot on Sunday, an escalation by one of the world’s richest men in a battle to control the future of A.I.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Nanna Heitmann
title: Long Lines of Russian Voters Signal Discontent With Putin’s Tenure
description: Many appeared to be heeding a call by the opposition to express frustration by showing up en masse at midday. “We don’t have any other options,” said one woman.
content: Russian voters formed long lines outside polling stations in major cities during the presidential election on Sunday, with many saying they were heeding a call by opposition leaders to protest a rubber-stamp process that is certain to keep Vladimir V. Putin in power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: A Video Captures a Searing Portrait of the Subway, and of the City Above
description: A nearly five-minute recording of a fight on the A train shows New York’s gravest problems, like illegal guns and mental illness, distilled in a single subway car.
content: It always seems to start the same way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Christopher Mele
title: Biden Mixes Comedy With Dire Warnings on Democracy at Washington Gala
description: “One candidate’s too old and mentally unfit to be president,” President Biden said at the Gridiron Club’s annual dinner. “The other guy’s me.”
content: President Biden delivered a mix of jokes and pointed criticisms at the expense of the presumptive Republican nominee, former President Donald J. Trump, at the Gridiron Club dinner in Washington on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David C. Adams and Frances Robles
title: Haiti’s Hospitals Survived Cholera and Covid. Gangs Are Closing Them.
description: Many hospitals in Haiti’s capital have been looted by gangs or abandoned by their staffs amid the violence. Some are open, but too dangerous for people in need of care to reach.
content: Taïna Cenatus, a 29-year-old culinary student in Haiti, lost her balance at school one day this month and toppled over, but it was not until she hit the ground that she realized she had been hit in the face by a stray bullet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Piety and Profanity: The Raunchy Christians Are Here
description: In the Trump era, a surprising number of evangelicals are rejecting modesty and turning toward the risqué.
content: The “Conservative Dad’s Real Women of America” 2024 pinup calendar features old-school images of sexiness — bikinis, a red sports car, a bubble bath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Tough
title: The Foreign Language That Changed My Teenage Son’s Life
description: I worried about his ability to fit in. But then he fell in love with Russian — and on a trip to Central Asia, he flourished.
content: Even as a little kid, my son Max had a way of immersing himself in the subjects he cared about. The first one I can remember was Thomas the Tank Engine. Max had a hand-me-down wooden train track set up on a low platform in our living room, and at age 3, he would spend hours toddling around the outside, pushing trains and telling made-up stories, lost in the world of Thomas and Percy and Gordon. “Hamilton” came next, the soundtrack on repeat in the car for months, then a brief but intense dive into Mixels, a discontinued Lego collection, and then another into a Roblox game called Bee Swarm Simulator. With each one, Max would go deep, finding satisfaction not just in the playing but also in the experience of plunging himself into a new and unfamiliar world and mastering all of its contours.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘Practically Fasting for Months’: A Joyless Ramadan in Gaza
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 17, 2024.
content: “There is no joy, no songs of Ramadan, no sweets of Ramadan. This has all been exterminated.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: ‘Winterreise’ Review: Hiding a Roiling Grief
description: On Friday, the pianist Mitsuko Uchida and the tenor Mark Padmore illuminated the bleakness of Schubert’s genre-defining song cycle at Zankel Hall.
content: It was a performance of hard-won wisdom. When the eminent pianist Mitsuko Uchida and the tenor Mark Padmore teamed up for Schubert’s “Winterreise” on Friday at Zankel Hall, they brought the maturity of hindsight to a genre-defining work of young, unrequited love. The concert was part of Uchida’s Perspectives series with Carnegie Hall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: New York Must Figure Out How to Fix Cannabis Mess, Hochul Orders
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul ordered a review of the way New York State licenses cannabis businesses after calling the sluggish rollout of legal cannabis a “disaster.”
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul has told New York officials to come up with a fix for the way the state licenses cannabis businesses amid widespread frustration over the plodding pace of the state’s legal cannabis rollout and the explosion of unlicensed dispensaries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh and Michael Gold
title: Trump Says Some Migrants Are ‘Not People’ and Predicts a ‘Blood Bath’ if He Loses
description: In a caustic and discursive speech in Ohio, former President Donald J. Trump once again doubled down on a doomsday vision of the United States.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump, at an event on Saturday ostensibly meant to boost his preferred candidate in Ohio’s Republican Senate primary race, gave a freewheeling speech in which he used dehumanizing language to describe immigrants, maintained a steady stream of insults and vulgarities and predicted that the United States would never have another election if he did not win in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Prudence Peiffer
title: With Bold Colors and Big Feelings, a Pioneering Painter Tells Her Story
description: In “With Darkness Came Stars,” the photorealist Audrey Flack offers a vivid, gossipy chronicle of her career among some of New York City’s most famous artists.
content: Now in her 90s, Audrey Flack still fights the urge to leap over the edge of the Guggenheim Museum’s rotunda, “not to kill myself, mind you, just to swoop around the atrium.” This image captures the formidable personality behind “With Darkness Came Stars,” Flack’s memoir of her career as a New York artist who graduated from art school at the height of Abstract Expressionism in the early 1950s, hung out with Willem de Kooning, Franz Kline and Jackson Pollock at the Cedar Bar in the Village and gained renown as the lone woman in a group known as “photorealists” for canvases brimming with high-definition detail — many of which are reproduced here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg and Steven Lee Myers
title: How Trump’s Allies Are Winning the War Over Disinformation
description: Their claims of censorship have successfully stymied the effort to filter election lies online.
content: In the wake of the riot on Capitol Hill on Jan. 6, 2021, a groundswell built in Washington to rein in the onslaught of lies that had fueled the assault on the peaceful transfer of power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Shane Goldmacher
title: Biden’s $53 Million February Haul Fuels Money Edge Over Trump
description: The president’s campaign and affiliated groups, including the D.N.C., hold a significant cash-on-hand advantage over Donald J. Trump and Republicans, as Mr. Trump continues to spend on legal bills.
content: President Biden’s re-election campaign said on Sunday that it had raised more than $53 million in February together with the Democratic Party, an influx of cash that is expected to widen the Democrats’ cash advantage in a general-election contest against former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: Crafting a Universe in Clay
description: The ceramic artist Toshiko Takaezu is getting a posthumous reappraisal, thanks to her devoted acolytes — and major shows highlighting her poetic forms.
content: There was no excuse that Toshiko Takaezu, a formidable ceramist, deemed acceptable when students missed her class at Princeton University’s Program in Visual Arts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Rich Braise From a Cheap Cut
description: Boneless beef chuck burbles with maple syrup, caramelized tomato paste, thyme, soy sauce and bay leaves in Vallery Lomas’s bourbon-braised beef.
content: Good morning. Happy St. Patrick’s Day to all those who celebrate. I like corned beef and cabbage myself for the holiday — Irish American food to ship up to Boston with, soda bread on the side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Putin Breaks Silence on Navalny’s Death, Calling It an ‘Unfortunate Incident’
description: The Russian leader claimed he had been ready to release Navalny in a prisoner swap when the opposition leader died last month at an Arctic penal colony.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin described the death of the imprisoned opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny as an “unfortunate incident” and claimed he had been ready to release him in exchange for Russian prisoners held in the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Egill Bjarnason and Yan Zhuang
title: Iceland Volcano Erupts in Plumes of Fire With Little Notice
description: The authorities said the eruption on Saturday night was the most powerful of a series that started in December.
content: A volcano erupted with little notice in southern Iceland on Saturday night, the latest in a string of eruptions in the area, threatening local infrastructure and leading the authorities to declare a state of emergency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Navalny’s Widow Casts Her Ballot in Berlin
description: Yulia Navalnaya, who has vowed to carry on her husband’s work, waited in line for hours with voters outside of the Russian embassy.
content: Yulia Navalnaya, the widow of the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny, lined up with voters outside the Russian embassy in Berlin on Sunday, in one of her few public appearances since her husband’s death last month.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Really Causes Poor Performance in School
description: Responses to a column by Nicholas Kristof about schools’ inadequacies. Also: A lefty in the G.O.P.; countering fossil fuel industry propaganda.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sonia Faleiro
title: The Spectacle of the Ambani Wedding Event Reveals India’s Inequality
description: Money and Power in Modi’s India
content: Rihanna, Mark Zuckerberg, bejeweled elephants and 5,500 drones. Those were some of the highlights of what is likely the most ostentatious “pre-wedding” ceremony the modern world has ever seen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds and Lauren Fox Kanan
title: In Kansas City, a Festive Yet Cautious St. Patrick’s Day Parade
description: A sizable but smaller crowd gathered one month after the Super Bowl parade shooting. Some were wary, but many were determined to not let the tragedy disrupt a treasured tradition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefano Montali
title: Kali Reis Fought Her Way to HBO. What’s Next?
description: The “True Detective” star, who first made her name in the boxing ring, isn’t scared of online trolling — even by the creator of her show.
content: Two days after the finale of HBO’s “True Detective: Night Country,” Kali Reis was rolling hand wraps, alone, inside a training center on a farm in northern New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arijeta Lajka and Caroline Kim
title: Rescue Worker Says Northern Gaza Is a ‘Catastrophe in Every Way’
description: As famine looms, a rescue worker with the Gaza government’s Palestinian Civil Defense gives a first-hand account of life on the ground amid Israel’s bombing of northern Gaza.
content: As famine looms, a rescue worker with the Gaza government’s Palestinian Civil Defense gives a first-hand account of life on the ground amid Israel’s bombing of northern Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Volcano Erupts in Southwestern Iceland
description: The eruption occurred near the town of Grindavik, prompting an evacuation of the region.
content: The eruption occurred near the town of Grindavik, prompting an evacuation of the region.
source.name: The New York Times
